header.title: The New Writings of Rav Ashlag: Article on World Peace Part 12

central_thesis: The fundamental spiritual qualities of Mercy, Truth, Righteousness, and Peace are inherently contradictory and conflicting when manifested in human nature and society, leading to internal and external strife, thus preventing true world peace until a higher, unifying spiritual consciousness is attained.

structure_content.summary: Reviews previous lessons, emphasizing 'Peace makers,' the concept that 'Truth is Destruction; Mercy is Construction,' and the ideal that 'The Entire World is one community & One Society.' These points establish the foundational principles against which the inherent conflicts of qualities will be examined.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction to Class 12: The Qualities of Mercy, Truth, Righteousness and Peace Fight One Another
structure_content.summary: Introduces the core topic of the article: the pervasive conflict among the spiritual qualities of Mercy, Truth, Righteousness, and Peace. It highlights that this conflict is a 'great war' within human psychological tendencies and impedes societal harmony, affecting individuals and groups alike.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Contradiction of Mercy and Truth
structure_content.summary: Analyzes the opposition between Mercy, defined as selfless giving ('mine is yours and yours is yours'), and Truth, implicitly defined by ownership and self-reliance ('mine is mine and yours is yours'). It explains that Mercy negates the need for Truth and Judgment, while Truth deems Mercy unfair, advocating for individual provision and foresight to avoid being a burden or deceitful to heirs.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Contradiction of Peace and Righteousness
structure_content.summary: Examines how societal Peace, in its current manifestation, maintains a status quo where the 'energetic and clever' prosper at the expense of the 'neglectful and naïve.' This state is inherently unjust and opposes Righteousness, which seeks a fair allocation of wealth. Conversely, an attempt to enforce Righteousness would disrupt the existing societal peace, leading to resistance from the powerful.

structure_content.chapter_title: Internal and Societal Conflict of Qualities
structure_content.summary: Concludes that these four qualities ('lock horns and fight with each other') are fundamentally incompatible in their unrectified state, creating conflict not only between different societal factions but also within each individual. It asserts that conventional reason cannot reconcile them into a harmonious agreement, as each obstructs the other's domain.

key_concepts.definition: A spiritual quality defined as complete altruism, where 'mine is yours and yours is yours,' leading to a dissolution of personal ownership and the necessity for Truth or Judgment.

A spiritual quality opposing Mercy, emphasizing individual ownership, self-reliance ('mine is mine and yours is yours'), and the necessity for honesty, even if it leads to 'destruction' or disruption of false harmony.

A quality concerned with just and equitable distribution, particularly of wealth and resources, aiming to prevent extreme suffering for the neglected and naïve, even if it disrupts established societal structures.

In its societal manifestation, a state where current conditions ensure the prosperity of the 'energetic and clever' while the 'neglectful and naïve' remain impoverished, implicitly resisting any change that would reallocate resources.

The central thesis that Mercy, Truth, Righteousness, and Peace, when expressed in human consciousness and society, are inherently contradictory and cannot coexist harmoniously without a higher, unifying principle, leading to constant conflict.

Though not explicitly defined in the text, it is an implicit goal within Rav Ashlag's Qabalistic system, implying the harmonization and elevation of these conflicting qualities to their divine, unified source, thereby achieving true peace.

practical_system.description: This article serves as a foundational philosophical diagnosis within the broader Qabalistic system of Rav Ashlag, rather than an explicit practical manual. It delineates the inherent and seemingly irreconcilable conflicts between fundamental divine qualities (Mercy, Truth, Righteousness, Peace) as they manifest in human nature and society. The operative implication for a practitioner is that true 'World Peace' and individual rectification (Tikkun) cannot be achieved by merely emphasizing one quality over another or by common sense arbitration, but rather through a higher, unifying spiritual consciousness. This understanding is a crucial prerequisite for engaging in Qabalistic practices aimed at balancing and harmonizing these forces, often through the development of altruistic intention (desire to bestow) and spiritual elevation that transcends the limited, self-centered manifestation of these qualities.
tools: Not explicitly detailed. The primary 'tool' presented here is intellectual and spiritual discernment – the capacity to recognize the inherent contradictions of these qualities when expressed without a higher, unifying principle. This discernment prepares the practitioner for further Qabalistic study and practice, which would involve concepts like the Screen (Masach), the Light (Ohr), and the intention of bestowal (Hashpa'a).
rituals: Not explicitly detailed in this specific article. In the broader Qabalistic context, rituals and meditations often involve contemplating and balancing sephirotic energies, such as those associated with Chesed (Mercy), Gevurah (Truth/Judgment), and Tiferet (Harmony/Peace/Righteousness), through prayer, study (Torah lishmah), and specific visualizations or intentions.

relevant_quotes.text: Truth is Destruction; Mercy is Construction
The Entire World is one community & One Society
The qualities of Mercy, Truth, Righteousness and Peace Fight One Another
because the quality of Mercy is understood and defined as a person saying 'mine is yours and yours is yours,' as our sages said in the Mishnah (Avot [Fathers] 5).
And with regards to Truth, which is defined by the saying 'mine is mine and yours is yours,' is in opposition to the quality of Mercy and cannot stand it at all.

In similar fashion, Peace is opposite to Righteousness, because in order to create Peace in society, the present conditions must remain as they are to guarantee that the energetic and clever would become rich, and the neglectful and naïve would remain poor.
This means that there is no Righteousness whatsoever in the conditions set by Peace; Peace is opposite to Righteousness.
Thus you see, how these qualities within us lock horns and fight with each other, not only between one sect of society and another, but also within each individual as well.

critical_analysis.relevance: The text is deeply rooted in the practical Qabalah of Rav Yehuda Ashlag, which emphasizes the rectification (Tikkun) of the soul and the world through the harmonization of divine attributes. Historically, Ashlag sought to make Qabalah accessible and applicable to contemporary societal challenges, particularly the pursuit of global peace. This article's analysis of the conflict between Mercy (Chesed), Truth/Judgment (Gevurah), Righteousness, and Peace (often associated with Tiferet) reflects a core Qabalistic dilemma: how the divine emanations, perfect in themselves, become distorted and contradictory in the lower worlds and human consciousness. Unlike earlier, more theoretical Qabalistic texts, Ashlag's approach aims for direct application to human behavior and societal structure. The recognition of these inherent contradictions is a foundational step in his system, which posits that true peace and unity can only be achieved by elevating these qualities to a higher spiritual intention, transcending their 'self-serving' or limited human manifestations. This contrasts with more simplistic ethical frameworks that might advocate for one quality over another, highlighting the complexity inherent in Qabalistic thought.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Students of Qabalah, particularly those following the lineage of Rav Ashlag and The Kabbalah Centre. Individuals interested in esoteric ethics, spiritual philosophy, and the practical application of spiritual principles to societal issues. Those grappling with the inherent contradictions in ethical systems and seeking a deeper spiritual understanding of human conflict.
